cards.title: LINKED USER REQUESTS
cards.description: User requests can be linked because they contain a unique identifier.
questions: Is there an identifier (unique in system/session) or dataset?
Is there other data associated with that identifier?
Is there previous data with the same identifier to which new data can be linked?

cards.title: LINKABLE USER REQUESTS
cards.description: User requests can be linked because they contain attributes that can be combined into quasi-identifiers.
questions: Is there a set of attributes that can serve as an identifier?
Is there other data sent together with that quasi-identifier?
Is there existing data to link it to?

cards.title: LINKING THROUGH DISTINGUISHABLE PATTERNS
cards.description: Patterns in the (meta)data contained in user requests can be used to link them to each other.
questions: Is the data from different individuals distinguishable?
Is it possible to query data using distinguishable attributes?

cards.title: LINKABLE DATASET
cards.description: Stored personal data can be linked to individuals.
questions: Is there a set of attributes that can serve as an identifier?
Is there other data sent together with that quasi-identifier?
Is there existing data to link it to?

cards.title: PROFILING USERS
cards.description: Users can be profiled by analyzing their data for patterns.
questions: Are there patterns derivable from the data?
Can (new) personal data be inferred from the linked data points?

cards.title: IDENTIFIED USER REQUESTS
cards.description: The incoming user requests contain data that directly reveals the user identity.
questions: Does data sent to the system (potentially) contain identity data?

cards.title: IDENTIFIABLE USER REQUESTS
cards.description: The user can be identified because the data in their requests can be used to infer who they are.
questions: Are requests or records sufficiently unique to differentiate them from those of a speciﬁc individual?

cards.title: IDENTIFIABLE DATA FLOWS
cards.description: Data sent to the system is sufficiently revealing to identify the user.
questions: Is there free-form user provided data that is received of processed by the system?
Is data collected that may reveal the identifying information?

cards.title: IDENTIFIERS IN DATA REQUESTS
cards.description: Communication contains (quasi-)identifiers.
questions: Is there a distinctive identifier used during interactions or when referring to an individual’s data?
Can multiple attributes be combined to create a unique reference to an individual or their data?

cards.title: IDENTIFIABLE DATASET
cards.description: Stored data can be used to identify individuals.
questions: Is there a distinctive identifier used during interactions or when referring to an individual’s data?
Can multiple attributes be combined to create a unique reference to an individual or their data?

cards.title: NON-REPUDIATION OF SERVICE USAGE
cards.description: Users cannot deny having used a service because of authentication or logged access.
questions: Does the system record data affecting deniability?
Does the data itself impact deniability claims?

cards.title: NON-REPUDIATION OF SENDING
cards.description: Users cannot deny having sent a message.
questions: Is the data digitally signed?
Which keys are used for signing? Who has access to these keys to verify signatures?

cards.title: NON-REPUDIATION OF RECEIPT
cards.description: Users cannot deny having received a message.
questions: Do (passive) interactions with the system (e.g., receiving a message) have side-effects (e.g., trigger transmissions, logging)?
Is deniability of receipt a desired feature for the system?

cards.title: NON-REPUDIATION OF STORAGE
cards.description: Users cannot deny claims about data stored in non-repudiable storage.
questions: Is the data digitally signed?
Which keys are used for signing? Who has access to these keys to verify signatures?

cards.title: NON-REPUDIATION OF HIDDEN DATA OR METADATA
cards.description: Hidden or metadata in a document prevent users from denying claims associated with it.
questions: Does stored or transmitted data have associated metadata?
Are there embedded data or hidden patterns in the data or transmissions?
Does this data lead to undesirable deniability issues?

cards.title: DETECTABLE USERS
cards.description: Inferring the existence of a user from the system’s response.
questions: Does the system show status messages (informational, warnings, errors) when retrieving data?
Are the status messages distinct when an item (a file, user, . . .) does not exist compared to not having access rights?

cards.title: DETECTABLE SERVICE USAGE
cards.description: Detecting communication between a service and its users.
questions: Can the communication be observed?
Can information be inferred from the observed communications?

cards.title: DETECTABLE EVENTS
cards.description: Detecting side effects or communications triggered by application events.
questions: Do actions in the system have side effects (e.g., saving a file, writing to a log, triggering other transmissions)?
Are these side effects observable?

cards.title: DETECTABLE RECORDS
cards.description: Detecting the existence of records in a system.
questions: Does the system show status messages (informational, warnings, errors) when retrieving data?
Are the status messages distinct when an item (a file, user, . . .) does not exist compared to not having access rights?

cards.title: EXCESSIVELY SENSITIVE DATA COLLECTED
cards.description: The system acquires more sensitive or finegrained data than strictly necessary for its functionality.
questions: Is the data more sensitive than strictly necessary?
Is the data more fine-grained than strictly necessary?
Does the data encoding include additional (meta)data?

cards.title: EXCESSIVE AMOUNT OF DATA COLLECTED
cards.description: The system acquires more data than strictly needed for its functionality.
questions: Is the amount of collected data necessary for the correct functioning of the system?
Is the processing frequency necessary?
Are there more data subjects involved than necessary?

cards.title: UNNECESSARY DATA ANALYSIS
cards.description: Data is further processed, analyzed, or enriched in a way that is not strictly necessary for the functionality.
questions: Is the data enrichment/analysis necessary for the system’s functionality?

cards.title: UNNECESSARY DATA RETENTION
cards.description: Data is stored for longer than needed.
questions: Is the data stored for longer time than necessary?

cards.title: OVEREXPOSURE OF PERSONAL DATA
cards.description: Personal data is shared with more services or external parties than necessary.
questions: Is the data necessary for the recipient?
Are there more parties involved than necessary?
How accessible is the data (public/limited/private)?

cards.title: INSUFFICIENT TRANSPARENCY
cards.description: Data subjects are insufficiently informed about the collection and processing of their personal data.
questions: Are data subjects insufficiently informed about the processing of personal data, including the purposes and methods of the processing involved?

cards.title: INSUFFICIENT INFORMATION WHEN SHARING DATA OF OTHERS
cards.description: When sharing personal data of others, users are insufficiently informed about the further data processing.
questions: If a user shares personal data of others, is it clear what, why, and how that data is further processed?

cards.title: INSUFFICIENT PRIVACY CONTROLS
cards.description: Data subjects have insufficient controls to manage their preferences.
questions: Does the system enable the data subject to configure which personal data is processed and for what purposes?
Can the data subject alter their preferences afterwards?

cards.title: INSUFFICIENT ACCESS
cards.description: Data subjects do not have access to their personal data.
questions: Do data subjects lack the ability to access the personal data being collected, processed, stored, or disclosed about them?

cards.title: INSUFFICIENT RECTIFICATION OR ERASURE
cards.description: Data subjects cannot rectify or erase their personal data.
questions: Do data subjects have the ability to correct or delete their personal data?

cards.title: NON-COMPLIANCE OF PROCESSING WITH APPLICABLE REGULATIONS
cards.description: The processing of personal data by the system is not compliant with applicable privacy regulations.
questions: Will the system be used in jurisdictions with specific rules for personal data processing (e.g., the EU)?
Does the system, or its processing activities, violate one or more rules in these applicable regulation(s)?

cards.title: NON-ADHERENCE TO PRIVACY STANDARDS
cards.description: The system is not compliant with privacy standards and best practices.
questions: Are there any (industry) specific privacy standards that are applicable to the system?
Does the system adequately implement the principles and controls outlined in these standards?

cards.title: IMPROPER DATA LIFECYCLE MANAGEMENT
cards.description: Data is not properly managed throughout its entire lifecycle within the system.
questions: Is there a data lifecycle management policy defined for the data processed within the system?
Does the policy outline clear principles for each phase of the data lifecycle (creation, storage, sharing and usage, archival, and destruction)?

cards.title: INSUFFICIENT SECURITY OF PROCESSING
cards.description: Data security measures and processes do not adhere to risk and security management best practices and standards.
questions: Is there an established process to manage security risks and identify the required countermeasures?
Does the system incorporate the required countermeasures?
Are the countermeasures aligned with industry standards and best practices?
